42.text:
So, Jane Eyre in lots of ways, borrows from
fairytales and folktales, so in some ways,

47.text:
Jane's story is like a Cinderella story - she's
somebody who, she's low and she's despised

53.text:
and her richer relatives think nothing of
her, but by the end of the story, she's married

58.text:
the handsome prince and he's not quite as
handsome as he was at the beginning of the

63.text:
book. But still, it's got all those elements
in it, but at the same time, it's also got

67.text:
another story which is the Bluebeard story,
so Bluebeard is a man who keeps marrying a

73.text:
procession of virgin brides and killing them
and then the last one in the sequence opens

80.text:
the cupboard door and finds the bodies of
the previous wives. And, of course, Jane Eyre

85.text:
finds a secret hidden away in the house too
of the previous wife - while she's not dead,

90.text:
but she's mad and deeply disturbing and distressing
figure in the book. But you see the way that

97.text:
she draws on those two stories, but then also
brings them together with much more realistic

102.text:
elements, you know the lack of food, the quite
realistic descriptions of the school that

107.text:
she went to - they're all there in the early
scenes and it's that brilliant bringing together

114.text:
of those two very different elements I think
that so powers those novels and gives them

119.text:
this kind of both a deeply realistic sense,
but also this mythical kind of power that

126.text:
enables them to speak to so many different
places and times.

139.text: I think what Gothic enables them to bring

141.text:
to the novel, is a way of extending the emotional
range and the kind of questions that it raises.

149.text:
So, theirs is a much more psychological Gothic
in a way, so that it's a way of exploring

154.text:
strange states of mind, of not being sure
of who you are, of uncanny moments and this

161.text:
is something called the New Gothic, which
is this much more psychological kind, not

166.text:
in which the scary things are necessarily
outside yourself, but somehow they're deep

170.text:
within yourself. So, one of the most interesting
of those Gothic uses is the way that there's

177.text:
a lot of insecurity about identity in Jane
Eyre. So, if you think early on, you know,

182.text:
when she's put in the red room, it becomes
from being a quite naturalistic or realistic

188.text:
kind of place, something much stranger and
weirder than that - it's like death, it's

196.text:
like the deepest kind of fears in your unconscious
mind somehow come to haunt Jane at that moment

203.text:
and it is a novel with a lot of haunting in
it. There's that moment when Jane seems to

208.text:
communicate telepathically with Rochester
and when she calls out to him, she cries out

213.text:
to him, but also you see it in the characters
too, so that there's a way in which although

219.text:
Bertha Mason is in some ways the opposite
of Jane, she's also uncannily and strangely

224.text:
linked to her as well and that, I think, is
something that draws quite deeply on Gothic

229.text:
tradition - the way that identity is never
simple or stable or belongs uniquely to you

234.text:
and that constantly you might find doubles,
or projections, or hauntings, or ghosts of

241.text:
yourself, popping up all over the place within
the world. You remember the first time Jane

245.text:
Eyre meets Rochester - it's on a lonely road
at night and he seems like a supernatural

251.text:
presence. It's like a Gytrash - well Charlotte
Brontë learned about the Gytrash here in

255.text:
this very house and so already at the first
meeting of two realistic modern people, he's

263.text:
already haunted by the possibility that there
might be some supernatural force, something

268.text: beyond them, just at the edge of their consciousness.
